bug.author: marwan116
bug.summary: Kubeflow Deployment on AWS EKS fails due to "webhook.cert-manager.io"
bug.description:
/kind bug What steps did you take and what happened: I attempted to deploy Kubeflow on AWS EKS (built using eksctl ). Tool versions that I am using:
eksctl version v0.17.0 kubectl version v1.15.5 (Client version), v1.15.11 (Server Version) aws-iam-authenticator v0.5.0 kfctl v1.0.2
Below are the steps that I took:
I unpack the tar ball to get the kfctl binary
I create the envrionment variables as shown in the documentation (https://www.kubeflow.org/docs/aws/deploy/install-kubeflow/) Note - I use the CONFIG_URI corresponding to AWS setup without authentication ("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kubeflow/manifests/v1.0-branch/kfdef/kfctl_aws.v1.0.2.yaml")
I get the kctl_aws.yaml file given the CONFIG_URI by callingwget -O kfctl_aws.yaml $CONFIG_URI
I configure kubeflow - here I tried both approaches: (using IAM for service account, where I edit the kfct_aws.yaml file to add enablePodIamPolicy : true ... and using node group roles, where I retrieve the IAM role name and update the yaml file accordingly)
I then call kfctl apply -V -f kfct_aws.yaml to deploy kubeflow - this results in multiple "encountered error" warnings: below is one of them - note that all warnings are cert-manager related .... WARN[0549] Encountered error applying application cert-manager: (kubeflow.error): Code 500 with message: Apply.Run Error error when creating "/tmp/kout158057241": Internal error occurred: failed calling webhook "webhook.cert-manager.io": the server is currently unable to handle the request filename="kustomize/kustomize.go:202"
Note - to delete kubeflow namespaces and CRDs - I had to manually add the clustername to the KfDef metadata in the kfct_aws.yml file ... What did you expect to happen: I expected the deployment to complete successfully and then to be able to port-forward to view kubeflow using localhost **Full error logs (personal info redacted) ** <denchmark-code>INFO[0000] No name specified in KfDef.Metadata.Name; defaulting to ifm-kf-test-1 based on location of config file: kfctl_aws.yaml. filename="coordinator/coordinator.go:202" INFO[0000] Running `eksctl version` ... filename="utils/awsutil.go:71" INFO[0000] eksctl version: 0.17.0 filename="utils/awsutil.go:88" INFO[0000] **************************************************************** Notice anonymous usage reporting enabled using spartakus To disable it If you have already deployed it run the following commands: cd $(pwd) kubectl -n ${K8S_NAMESPACE} delete deploy -l app=spartakus

comments.comment:
Issue-Label Bot is automatically applying the labels:
Label Probability
kind/bug 0.99
Please mark this comment with or to give our bot feedback! Links: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/marketplace/issue-label-bot>app homepage</denchmark-link> , <denchmark-link:https://github.com/marketplace/issue-label-botdata/kubeflow/kubeflow>dashboard</denchmark-link> and <denchmark-link:https://github.com/hamelsmu/MLapp>code</denchmark-link> for this bot.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/marwan116>@marwan116</denchmark-link>
Trying to see without the cert-manager, can you visit dashboard? Did you install kubeflow on a cluster with kubeflow before? or a clean cluster?

Hey <denchmark-link:https://github.com/Jeffwan>@Jeffwan</denchmark-link> thank you for getting back to me on this - to answer your questions: Trying to see without the cert-manager, can you visit dashboard? so the very first time I tried this - I manually enabled IAM service account (associated an OIDC provider - and created an iamserviceraccount) - I wasn't aware that this is what kfctl was doing behind the scenes ... I was able to visit the kubeflow dashboard but it showed "no namespaces" and "Unable to contact Profile controller" ... Did you install kubeflow on a cluster with kubeflow before? or a clean cluster? So then I deleted the EKS cluster when this failed, then created a new EKS cluster using eksctl and tried again - this time just adding enablePodIamPolicy : true to the manifest ... this threw the cert-manager.io errors and I am not able to visit the kubeflow dashboard

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/Jeffwan>@Jeffwan</denchmark-link> - in short, I can't visit the dashboard and I attempted the deployment on a clean cluster. - any suggestions on debugging this ? As an aside - I saw this in the documentation: "The installation tool uses the eksctl command and doesn’t support the --profile option in that command. If you need to switch role, use the aws sts assume-role commands." I tried creating the cluster as a root user - and also as an IAM user with administrator privileges - I presume one thing I didnt try is as a user with temporary privileges using Assume Role - but I would be very surprised if that's the issue - correct ?

calling kubectl get apiservice v1beta1.webhook.cert-manager.io gives the following <denchmark-code>NAME SERVICE AVAILABLE AGE v1beta1.webhook.cert-manager.io cert-manager/cert-manager-webhook False (MissingEndpoints) 30m </denchmark-code>
AVAILABLE = False(MissingEndpoints) - any idea why that is ?

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/Jeffwan>@Jeffwan</denchmark-link> - interesting so I managed not to get the cert-manager.io error this time around, I only got a single warning and "seems to have worked" and I can access the dashboard ... The only change I made is my cluster.yaml config (the file I am using to create the cluster using eksctl) config file used to be: <denchmark-code>apiVersion: eksctl.io/v1alpha5 kind: ClusterConfig
metadata: name: <AWS_CLUSTER_NAME> region: <AWS_REGION>
nodeGroups: - name: ng-1 instanceType: t3.medium desiredCapacity: 1 minSize: 0 maxSize: 1 ssh: allow: true # will use ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub as the default ssh key </denchmark-code>
changed it to: <denchmark-code>apiVersion: eksctl.io/v1alpha5 kind: ClusterConfig metadata: name: <AWS_CLUSTER_NAME> region: <AWS_REGION> version: '1.14'
nodeGroups: - name: eks-cpu instanceType: t3.medium desiredCapacity: 3 minSize: 0 maxSize: 4 volumeSize: 30 ssh: allow: true publicKeyPath: '~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub'
</denchmark-code>
However, the dashboard is still not fully functional - it now says: Unable to contact Profile Controller and no-namespaces show in the drop-down ... here is the output from calling after waiting for a while after applying kfctl kubectl -n kubeflow get all <denchmark-code>NAME READY STATUS RESTARTS AGE pod/admission-webhook-bootstrap-stateful-set-0 1/1 Running 0 14m pod/admission-webhook-deployment-64cb96ddbf-mw8vp 1/1 Running 0 13m pod/alb-ingress-controller-688849647-bt9pm 0/1 Pending 0 12m pod/application-controller-stateful-set-0 1/1 Running 0 14m Ok I got it working - I changed the cluster configuration to: <denchmark-code>apiVersion: eksctl.io/v1alpha5 kind: ClusterConfig metadata: name: <AWS_CLUSTER_NAME> region: <AWS_REGION> version: '1.14'
nodeGroups: - name: eks-cpu instanceType: m5.xlarge desiredCapacity: 4 minSize: 0 maxSize: 5 volumeSize: 30 ssh: allow: true publicKeyPath: '~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub'
</denchmark-code>
basically all I did was upsize the instance from t3.medium to m5.xlarge - the cert-manager.io warnings are still there but they get resolved (i.e. dont end up in an error being thrown) and the ALB-ingress controller that was shown above as pending and the katib-db as failing were both crashing due to insufficient pods. Note: I wasn't aware of the pod limit on amazon instances (<denchmark-link:https://github.com/awslabs/amazon-eks-ami/blob/master/files/eni-max-pods.txt>https://github.com/awslabs/amazon-eks-ami/blob/master/files/eni-max-pods.txt</denchmark-link> ) - I think it would help those new to AWS EKS if a note was made about this in the documentation otherwise some might not provision enough compute in their cluster set up and end up bumping into these issues
thank you @Jeffwan @twittidai for the support ...
